image.altText: A barbed wire fence pictured through trees against an orange sky

items.synopsis: Despite repeated warnings and multiple opportunities to intervene, prison authorities failed to prevent 16-year-old Cleveland Dodd's death and wasted critical minutes, the ABC can reveal. WARNING: This story discusses incidents of self-harm.

title.children: There's been no clear picture about what happened to Cleveland Dodd in the notorious Unit 18 jail, until now

image.altText: A rally with someone holding up a big sign saying 'Justice for Cleveland Dodd'

items.synopsis: There were opportunities to save Cleveland Dodd before his death in youth detention. Yet the WA government failed to act, writes Keane Bourke. WARNING: This story discusses incidents of self-harm and the image of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Cleveland Dodd's death in detention was entirely foreseeable — yet no-one stopped it

image.altText: A hotel with police tap blocking off the area and road, while investigators wearing blue hazmat suits comb through debris

items.synopsis: Onlookers and locals describe the horrific scene that unfolded at a pub in Daylesford last night, where five people, including two children, died when a vehicle crashed through the beer garden.

title.children: 'Destroyed in an instant': Community in shock after 'beautiful night' ends with five dead

image.altText: A boy faces a teacher who is standing in front of a blackboard.

items.synopsis: A review of public education chaired by former premier Carmen Lawrence makes a scathing assessment of NAPLAN, calling for it to be replaced by an internationally recognised alternative.

title.children: Calls for NAPLAN to be scrapped, more regulation on independent schools in teachers' union-backed review

image.altText: A man walks on a footpath while a man holds a microphone seeking answers to questions.

items.synopsis: The former head of one of Perth's largest hospitals, Kempton Cowan, is sent to prison for five months for online child sex offences.

title.children: 'A chapter of his life he needs to put behind him': Former hospital boss jailed for online child sex offences

image.altText: A hand holds a remote pointed towards a large TV.

items.synopsis: Pricey entertainment subscription services are getting the chop from more Aussie households as consumers turn to free or cheaper ad-based content for entertainment, a new report reveals.

title.children: Australians are spending less on streaming services, but rising cost of living isn't the only reason why

image.altText: Spectators sit on the hill

items.synopsis: With Tests in Perth failing to attract big crowds, Cricket Australia is turning to an old favourite, the hill, to reignite passions in the west.

title.children: Can a makeshift hill recapture the hearts and minds of WA cricket fans?

image.altText: Two scam ads with photoshopped images of a man being arrested.

items.synopsis: The words emblazoned across the ads are dramatic, and they're usually accompanied by a photoshopped or AI-generated image of an Australian celebrity being arrested. It's an attempt to take your money.

title.children: 'I'm losing face and losing credibility': Richard Wilkins calls for a crackdown on photoshopped scam ads

image.altText: A man who works as a professor standing in front of a building with School of Mines written on the entrance.

items.synopsis: Water as valuable as gold in Western Australia's historic Goldfields as researchers try to find alternate sources for the state's booming mining sector.

title.children: In WA's outback, councils and miners are setting their sights on an increasingly scarce resource — water

image.altText: A photo of Donald Trump in a suit and tie, standing and pointing, next to a photo of Joe Biden in a jacket giving a thumbs up

items.synopsis: New polls show Joe Biden faces a tough road to securing another four years in the White House.

title.children: Trump leads Biden in key polls a year out from 2024 US election

image.altText: A burned out car with people around it in rescue gear late at night

items.synopsis: Hezbollah says "the enemy will pay the price" after an air strike, which Israel says was targeting terrorists, killed three children. While Jordan's king confirms a midnight aid air-drop. Follow live

title.children: Hezbollah says Israel to 'pay price' for Lebanon strike as Jordan airdrops aid in Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel says it has divided Gaza into two as it continues to encircle Gaza City. “Today there is north Gaza and south Gaza,” Israeli Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari told reporters. He called it a “significant stage” in Israel’s war against Hamas terrorists. Israeli media also reported troops were expected to enter Gaza City within 48 hours. Strong explosions were seen in northern Gaza after nightfall. Communications have been lost in Gaza for the third time. World Health Organization's director-general Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says he is concerned about the reports of another connectivity outage. "Without connectivity, people who need immediate medical attention cannot contact hospitals and ambulances," he said on social media. "All channels of communication must be restored immediately." Reporting with Associated Press
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel encircles Gaza City  in 'significant stage' of conflict

children.content: Israel says it has divided Gaza into two as it continues to encircle Gaza City.
“Today there is north Gaza and south Gaza,” Israeli Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari told reporters.
He called it a “significant stage” in Israel’s war against Hamas terrorists.
Israeli media also reported troops were expected to enter Gaza City within 48 hours.
Strong explosions were seen in northern Gaza after nightfall.
Communications have been lost in Gaza for the third time.
World Health Organization's director-general Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says he is concerned about the reports of another connectivity outage.
"Without connectivity, people who need immediate medical attention cannot contact hospitals and ambulances," he said on
social media.
"All channels of communication must be restored immediately."
Reporting with Associated Press

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Members of the Greens have walked out of parliament chambers in a fiery protest against Labor's position on the Israel-Gaza war. Greens Deputy Leader Mehreen Faruqi led what she labelled the "people's protest" inside parliament during Senate question time. "You are watching the massacre of thousands of Palestinians by Israel and you are not condemning Israel," Ms Faruqi said. "You refuse to call for an immediate ceasefire. "We are not going to sit here and watch you pat yourselves on the back for doing nothing." Ms Faruqi and her colleagues then left the chambers despite repeated calls for order. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has demonstrated support for Israel since Hamas's terrorist attack on Southern Israel on October 7 while expressing concern for Gaza civilians.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Free Palestine': Greens members walk out of Senate chambers in protest

children.content: Members of the Greens have walked out of parliament chambers in a fiery protest against Labor's position on the Israel-Gaza war.
Greens Deputy Leader Mehreen Faruqi led what she labelled the "people's protest" inside parliament during Senate question time.
"You are watching the massacre of thousands of Palestinians by Israel and you are not condemning Israel," Ms Faruqi said.
"You refuse to call for an immediate ceasefire.
"We are not going to sit here and watch you pat yourselves on the back for doing nothing."
Ms Faruqi and her colleagues then left the chambers despite repeated calls for order.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has demonstrated support for Israel since Hamas's terrorist attack on Southern Israel on October 7 while expressing concern for Gaza civilians.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jordan's King Abdullah says Jordan's air force personnel have "air-dropped at midnight urgent medical aid to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza". He said it is Jordan's duty and that it would always stand with Palestinians. "A royal air force plane dropped urgent medical aid using parachutes to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza whose supplies were about to run out due to the delay of delivering aid through Rafah crossing", Jordan's state news agency said citing a military source in the General Command of the Jordanian Armed Forces. After signing a peace treaty 30 years ago, Jordan and Israel have had a good political relationship, however with the current escalation the government has faced pressure to not only express their solidarity with Palestinians, but to take action. The King and Queen have criticised Israel's actions in Gaza and called for an immediate cease fire and Jordan's ambassador was recalled while the Israeli ambassador was told to stay away. You can read more about the challenges Jordan now faces here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan King: Air force airdropped urgent medical aid in Gaza

featuredLink.title: Why an 'extraordinary' statement by Queen Rania was the first sign of shifting priorities in Jordan

children.content: Jordan's King Abdullah says Jordan's air force personnel have "air-dropped at midnight urgent medical aid to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza".
He said it is Jordan's duty and that it would always stand with Palestinians.

"A royal air force plane dropped urgent medical aid using parachutes to the Jordanian field hospital in Gaza whose supplies were about to run out due to the delay of delivering aid through Rafah crossing", Jordan's state news agency said citing a military source in the General Command of the Jordanian Armed Forces.

After signing a peace treaty 30 years ago, Jordan and Israel have had a good political relationship, however with the current escalation the government has faced pressure to not only express their solidarity with Palestinians, but to take action.
The King and Queen have criticised Israel's actions in Gaza and called for an immediate cease fire and Jordan's ambassador was recalled while the Israeli ambassador was told to stay away.
You can read more about the challenges Jordan now faces here:

image.altText: Two men standing in an underground mine shaft

items.synopsis: Australia is known for blocking Chinese investment in critical minerals companies. As the country works towards net zero, an analyst warns we may need much greater investment from our biggest trading partner.

title.children: Chinese investment is crucial to Australia's energy transition. How will it happen?

image.altText: A man and woman standing together, the woman is holding a cat and smiling at the man.

items.synopsis: The Shire of Denmark is turning to infill and higher density housing in a bid to tackle the housing crisis that's forced young couples like Brad and Maria to leave town.

title.children: The housing shortage turned Maria from a resident into a tourist in her adopted home town

image.altText: Black and white photo of Libbi Gorr as Elle McFeast, hands wearing gloves holding chin, looking sultry at camera.

items.synopsis: Libbi Gorr shook up Australian television in the 1990s with her comic character Elle McFeast. A controversial interview saw her TV career tumble. This is how she found her way back.

title.children: A controversial interview ended Libbi Gorr's television career. But she still believes in risk

image.altText: A person on a small motorbike looks at the wreckage of a car as it lies in the front lawn of a home in Ashcroft in Sydney

items.synopsis: Two boys aged between 10 and 15 years old die in a car crash in Sydney's south-west, with police searching for another two people who allegedly fled the scene.

title.children: 'Absolute destruction': CCTV captures moment of fatal Sydney car crash, police searching for driver

image.altText: A dark-coloured seabird lies dead in the sand at a beach.

items.synopsis: Experts say the "confronting" sights that greeted NSW beachgoers was likely caused by bad weather, though other factors could also have been at play.

title.children: Hundreds of mutton birds found dead as 'wreck' strikes during 'epic' migration

image.altText: Stephen Gageler sitting in a courtroom wearing a black robe.

items.synopsis: Stephen Gageler has been sworn in as Australia's 14th Chief Justice of the High Court, taking on one of the most powerful jobs in the country.

title.children: New High Court chief justice formally acknowledges Indigenous Australians during swearing-in ceremony

image.altText: Photo of a woman's face with a rip through the middle.

items.synopsis: Vanessa trusted her psychologist – then she married her. Three years after her death, her family want answers.

title.children: This psychologist groomed her client, then married her. Now 20 years of deception are coming undone

image.altText: Pro sufer Matahi Drollet riding a barrel in the surf.

items.synopsis: One of the most famous surf breaks in the world, Teahupo’o, will host the Paris 2024 Olympics surfing competition  but locals say construction is threatening the tiny village's marine ecosystem, and the residents' health.

title.children: Paris 2024 Olympics environmental promises come unstuck on famous Tahiti reef

image.altText: a child shovels sand into a plastic bucket

items.synopsis: Kununurra's housing crisis is causing havoc with the town's childcare sector, as the local shire reveals plans to attract much-needed workers to the remote town.

title.children: Outback shire hopes modular homes will solve childcare woes

image.altText: A close-up shot of police tape with police vehicles in the background out of focus.

items.synopsis: A 35-year-old man has been charged with murder after a fatal shooting in the town of Wooroloo, in Perth's east, on Saturday. Police continue the search for two men involved in the incident.

title.children: Man charged with murder after fatal shooting in Perth's east that sent town into lockdown

image.altText: A close up shot of a man with white hair wearing a suit.

items.synopsis: A group of high-profile whistleblowers who helped spark royal commissions and change laws write an open letter to the federal government accusing it of overseeing a broken system that leaves whistleblowers exposed to costly legal fees — and worse.

title.children: If found guilty, whistleblower David McBride faces up to 100 years in prison. His fellow whistleblowers say that's a travesty

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Li Qiang shake hands against a blue backdrop.

items.synopsis: Chinese Australians and Australian expats in China are upbeat that the long-awaited PM visit may help reverse the "headwind" the relationship has been facing.

title.children: 'Good news for many Chinese Australians': High hopes for Albanese's China visit

image.altText: Steph and Gian sit on a couch looking shocked as their auction takes place.

items.synopsis: One couple has netted a staggering $1.6 million in profits after winning The Block, while another couple’s shaky auction saw them walk away with $65,000 in comparison. So, what do these wildly different results say about Australia’s housing market?

title.children: What The Block auctions tell us about Australia's housing market

image.altText: A man and woman hug next to police tape at Daylesford after a fatal crash.

items.synopsis: Police have revealed further details about the victims of a tragic car crash through the beer garden of a regional Victorian pub on Sunday, including that three of those who died were from one family.

title.children: Three of five people killed in beer garden crash were from one family, police say

image.altText: A drone and a jet flying through a clear blue sky

items.synopsis: As Israel deploys its fleet of sophisticated, expensive drones in its war against Hamas, the militant group has come armed with its own surprise: Cheap, off-the-shelf-drones rigged up to carry bombs.

title.children: Hamas is armed with a deadly surprise: Cheap Chinese drones transformed into weapons of war

image.altText: Workers walk along a path with a truck carrying supplies, on the way to Kibbutz Yasur.

items.synopsis: Since their origins in 1910, Israel's kibbutzim have changed dramatically, leaving them as vulnerable communities clustered near a war zone.

title.children: What is a kibbutz? Even before Hamas's attacks, much had changed in these Israeli communes

image.altText: A Hanshin Tigers fan wearing Colonel Sanders costume and holding a KFC bucket

items.synopsis: Sport is legendary for its curses — but Japanese baseball ended its most famous one on Sunday when Hanshin Tigers ended its KFC curse after 38 years.

title.children: 'The Curse of the Colonel': Why these Japanese baseball fans tossed a man dressed as Colonel Sanders into a fetid river

image.altText: A man sits at a table and looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Leaked documents reveal the NT government's private security guards are not authorised to move on people sleeping rough. But Rodney Taylor says it frequently happens to him.

title.children: NT security guards unlawfully moving on sleeping homeless people in Darwin

image.altText: Pilot Deborah Lawrie smiling at airport

items.synopsis: Captain Deborah Lawrie was denied a job by Reginald Ansett for being a woman. Now her name will have pride of place on a bridge that goes over Reginald Ansett Drive, and the irony has not escaped her.

title.children: Bridge named after trailblazing female pilot to pass over road honouring man who didn't want her to fly

image.altText: A bald man in a Hawaiian shirt standing in front of a tree.

items.synopsis: The case against a former daycare worker, accused of sexually abusing 91 children under his care, could bypass the lower court.

title.children: Case of daycare worker facing child sex abuse charges may bypass lower court through ex officio indictment

image.altText: Striking SAG AFTRA member holds up sign saying corporate exploitation stinks

items.synopsis: From George Clooney offering up his pay cheque to suspended talks — there has been a growing effort to try and end Hollywood's prolonged strikes. Could this new development end the picket?

image.altText: two women facing away from the camera leaning on each other in an embrace

items.synopsis: School is the highlight of Brittany's* life, but the Queensland high school student, who has a disability, is rarely there.

title.children: School is the highlight of Brittany's life, but a 'very concerning' trend means she's rarely there

image.altText: view of singular building with significant damage, surrounded by rubble

items.synopsis: Evacuations of injured people and foreign nationals from the Gaza Strip into Egypt have stopped since Israel's deadly attack on an ambulance on Saturday, and as strikes from Israel continue to hit refugee camps in the enclave.

title.children: Evacuations from Gaza suspended as refugee camps struck by Israel
